security_audit.summary: The skill performs financial ratio calculations with no network access, file operations, or code execution. It uses safe mathematical operations with zero-division protection. Minor concerns include lack of input validation and potential for information disclosure through error messages.

medium_findings.title: Missing Input Validation
medium_findings.description: Financial data inputs lack validation for data types and reasonable ranges. The code accepts any numeric values without checking for negative values where inappropriate (e.g., negative revenue, assets) or unrealistic magnitudes that could indicate data corruption or malicious input.

medium_findings.title: No Data Structure Validation
medium_findings.description: Input dictionaries are accessed without validating required fields exist. The code uses .get() with defaults but doesn't verify the overall data structure contains necessary financial statement sections (income_statement, balance_sheet, etc.) before processing.

low_findings.title: Potential Information Disclosure
low_findings.description: Error messages from mathematical operations or missing data could reveal system information. While the code uses safe division, other operations might expose stack traces or internal state in error conditions.

low_findings.title: Resource Exhaustion Potential
low_findings.description: Large datasets could consume excessive memory during processing. The code loads all financial data into memory and performs multiple calculations without size limits or pagination for very large inputs.

content.user_title: Analyze Financial Statements and Calculate Investment Ratios
content.value_statement: Stop manually calculating financial ratios from spreadsheets. This skill instantly analyzes income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow data to calculate profitability, liquidity, leverage, efficiency, and valuation ratios with industry benchmarks.
actual_capabilities: Calculate 20+ financial ratios including ROE, ROA, P/E, current ratio, debt-to-equity
Interpret ratios with industry-specific benchmarks for 5 major sectors
Generate trend analysis for multi-period financial data
Create formatted Excel reports with ratio calculations and interpretations
Provide actionable recommendations based on ratio analysis
limitations: Requires complete financial statement data for accurate calculations
Industry benchmarks are simplified averages, not company-specific
Cannot analyze qualitative factors or market sentiment
Historical analysis requires consistent data formatting across periods

use_cases.title: Quick Company Valuation Analysis
use_cases.description: Upload financial statements to instantly calculate P/E, EV/EBITDA, and other valuation multiples for investment decisions.

use_cases.title: Financial Health Checkup
use_cases.description: Analyze your company's liquidity, profitability, and leverage ratios to identify areas for improvement.

use_cases.title: Learn Financial Ratio Analysis
use_cases.description: Practice calculating ratios with sample data and understand what each metric means for business performance.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Ratio Calculation
prompt_templates.scenario: Calculate key ratios from financial statements
prompt_templates.prompt: Calculate the current ratio, debt-to-equity, and ROE for this company using the attached balance sheet and income statement data.

prompt_templates.title: Investment Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze these financial statements and tell me if this company is a good investment. Include P/E ratio, profit margins, and liquidity analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Industry Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Calculate financial ratios for this tech company and compare them to industry standards. Highlight any concerning metrics.

prompt_templates.title: Trend Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze the 3-year trend in profitability and efficiency ratios for this company. Identify improving or deteriorating metrics.

output_examples.input: Calculate key financial ratios for Apple Inc. using their latest annual report data
output: - Quick Ratio: 1.15 (Good - strong liquid asset position)
- P/E Ratio: 28.4 (Growth Premium - market expects continued growth)
- P/B Ratio: 8.2 (High - reflecting strong brand value)
Recommendation: Strong financial performance with premium valuation justified by market leadership.

best_practices: Always provide complete financial statements including income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow for most accurate analysis
Specify your industry when requesting analysis to get relevant benchmark comparisons
Include multiple periods of data for trend analysis to identify improving or deteriorating metrics
anti_patterns: Don't use incomplete or partial financial data as ratios may be misleading without full context
Avoid comparing ratios across very different industries without understanding sector-specific differences
Don't rely solely on ratios for investment decisions - consider qualitative factors and market conditions

faq.question: What financial data do I need to provide?
faq.answer: You need income statement, balance sheet, and optionally cash flow statement. Market data like share price is needed for valuation ratios.

faq.question: Which industries have specific benchmarks?
faq.answer: Technology, retail, financial services, manufacturing, and healthcare have tailored benchmarks. Other industries use general benchmarks.

faq.question: Can I analyze multiple years of data?
faq.answer: Yes, provide historical financial statements and the skill will calculate trends and show performance changes over time.

faq.question: How accurate are the industry comparisons?
faq.answer: Benchmarks are industry averages for guidance. For precise comparisons, use sector-specific or competitor data.

faq.question: What if my ratios seem unusual?
faq.answer: The skill flags unusual ratios and provides explanations. Unusual doesn't always mean bad - context matters.

faq.question: Can this replace professional financial analysis?
faq.answer: This tool provides quick analysis and insights but should complement, not replace, professional financial advisory services.
